description.text: In my third year of university, I developed a project inspired by libraries, envisioning a mysterious object to hide among the books, something that could blend in seamlessly while still catching the eye of passersby. After a research phase, I chose a chessboard as the central object: simple, intriguing, and embodying a sense of play and anticipation that could appeal to a diverse audience. The chessboard is designed to resemble a book: it closes like a bound volume, with a spine that mimics a classic cover, and the pieces inside are neatly arranged like books on a shelf.

I also conceptualized a window display strategy to heighten the sense of discovery. In the first display, the shadow of a chess piece is projected onto a white panel using a low, frontal light, creating visual compositions that tie back to the theme of libraries. In the second display, oversized chess pieces are arranged in a sequence, with some hidden behind others, continuing the theme of concealment. This project plays with the idea of hide-and-seek, the allure of the unknown, and the power of curiosity.
